Ayizu
Chief of the Masters of the Night-Wind, who fought alongside the Sentinel Knight 500 years ago. Although many people viewed Khaenri'ah as the cause of the tragedy, Ayizu was kind to Thrain and helped him in his time of need. In his final moments, Ayizu told Sentinel Knight about the Gnosis's ability to reconstruct the Ley Lines.
Sentinel Knight

Over five hundred years ago, before the Cataclysm, the heart of the Khaenri'ahn knight, Thrain, was enhanced with technology to convert memories and souls from the Ley Lines into knowledge. For his valiant and honorable possession of the heart, Thrain was given the title of the "Sentinel Knight." Like the four pillars of strength, he was to continue safeguarding the glory of Khaenri'ah. When the Cataclysm occurred, the
one of the Primordial One's shades, cursed all pureblooded Khaenri'ahns, including Thrain, with immortality for the use of the powers of the Abyss by the Five Sinners. Though most were innocent and unaware of the Sinners, they were doomed to the endless torment of the flesh and doomed to watch everything they loved perish.

When Khaenri'ah was destroyed, Capitano and the remnants of his platoon arrived in Natlan, where he fought shoulder to shoulder with other Natlanese against the Abyss. Although many of the people of Teyvat believed that Khaenri'ahns were responsible for the Cataclysm, the Masters of the Night-Wind's chief, Ayizu, was kind to Thrain and helped him in his time of need. After that, the Sentinel Knight decided to help the people of Natlan. Even if he could not save his homeland, he was determined to win. Ayizu could not escape his fate, and in his last moments, he told Thrain the secret of the Gnosis: its ability to reconstruct the Ley Lines at the cost of all the memories stored within them.

A side effect of Thrain's altered heart was a heightened sensitivity to souls. A long time ago, Natlan's Ley Lines were damaged, and so one of the angels, the Lord of the Night, created the Night Kingdom, recreating a network similar to the Ley Lines. After this, the first Pyro Archon and the Ruler of Death created the laws of the Ode of Resurrection, which made it impossible for Natlan's Ley Lines to connect with the Ley Lines of other countries. The Heavenly Principles changed them so that they could withstand the Abyss. When the Night Kingdom was corrupted by the Abyss, it could no longer contain the souls of all the dead, and they wandered the earth in torment. After seeing many homeless souls during the Cataclysm, he abandoned the idea of knowledge and began using his heart as a vessel for souls. The Sentinel Knight kept the souls of hundreds of his fallen comrades and Natlanese in his heart, but he could not find a way to put them to rest. When the souls merged, their voices echoed in his head, never ceasing for a second. Souls that retained the memories of their deaths cried, screamed, and moaned desperately. Because of these screams, Thrain knew no moment of peace and could not sleep for five hundred years of his immortality. Due to these trials, his body succumbed to erosion and decay, but he did not retreat from his intended purpose for a moment. Thrain tried to put the souls stored in his heart to rest in many countries, but not a single attempt was successful. The unique structure of the Ley Lines in Natlan later led Capitano there, since it was the only land capable of resting the souls he carried within himself.

customize.text: Il Capitano

After the Cataclysm was stopped and Teyvat was saved from the Abyss, Thrain joined the Fatui, an organization from Snezhnaya that serves the Cryo Archon, the Tsaritsa, and fights against the Heavenly Principles. He wanted to challenge the Ruler of Death, so his goals coincided with those of the "Warriors of the Pale Star." The Sentinel Knight abandoned his former name and took the name
becoming number one of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers. One of the Harbingers' tasks is to obtain the Gnoses, and Capitano was tasked with obtaining the Pyro Gnosis of Natlan. He wanted not only to obtain the artifact but also to use it to reconstruct the Ley Lines, which had only become more and more damaged over the past five hundred years. The Harbinger knew that the Pyro Archon, Mavuika, had devised a plan to save Natlan: she would use the power of six heroes of Natlan, who bore the Ancient Names of the people who had fought alongside the first Pyro Archons and the heroes who had died during the Cataclysm five hundred years earlier. With Natlan's time running out and heroes not yet recognized by their Ancient Names, Capitano knew this plan was too risky. If the heroes of Natlan did not arrive in time, not only Natlan, but all of Teyvat would pay for this mistake.

After arriving in Natlan with the elite warriors of the Fatui, the Harbinger wanted to speak to the great shaman of the Masters of the Night-Wind, Citlali, who understood the Night Kingdom best. During his search, he encountered Ororon of the Masters of the Night-Wind. Ororon wanted to protect Citlali, so he began to watch the Fatui. In order to obtain the Gnosis, the Harbinger traveled to the Stadium of the Sacred Flame to challenge the Pyro Archon to a duel, but was wounded in the heart after a tough battle. Ororon, sensing the strange presence of souls, saved Capitano with a spell so that he would not die, taking all the evidence with him. Just like the Harbinger, Ororon had a heightened sensitivity to souls, so he knew that the Ley Lines were weakening. After seeing Capitano send a soul to the Night Kingdom and hearing their plan to save Natlan, Ororon decided to join Capitano and help him in his plan.

After the duel with Mavuika, Capitano abandoned the idea of ​​using the Gnosis and asked the Tsaritsa to relieve him of the duty of obtaining the artifact, to which she responded in agreement. The Cryo Archon allows every Harbinger the freedom to pursue the meaning of their existence, even if that freedom can take precedence over her orders. Capitano's methods were radically different from some other Harbingers' methods despite sharing the same goal. Upon learning that the Traveler, the brother/sister of the Princess/Prince of Khaenri'ah, had arrived in Natlan, the Harbinger attempted to ally with them to help Natlan, but they refused. To find another way to restore the Ley Lines, the Fatui began studying the Source Mechanisms, a technology used by the ancient dragons to strengthen and empower the Ley Lines. This method was of little use in the time of the dragons, as they lacked the skills to navigate the intricate structure of the Ley Lines. Like using the Gnosis, this method required the sacrifice of everything contained within the existing Ley Lines: memories, souls, and history. Upon learning of the Fatui's plan, the Pyro Archon called for all forces to mobilize to destroy the Source Mechanism and prevent it from being activated. When Mavuika, the Traveler, and the heroes of Natlan found the mechanism, Capitano and Ororon activated it but were stopped. When activated, the Source Mechanism did not restore the Ley Lines but awakened the Lord of the Night from her slumber. Although the activation was incredibly painful, the Lord of the Night was able to absorb some of the power into herself, allowing her to speak and help the Natlanese. She was willing to restore the Ley Lines at the cost of her life, but this would destroy the rules of Natlan and leave the country vulnerable to an attack from the Abyss in the future.

customize.text: Merging with the Lord of the Night

After five of the six heroes were recognized by their Ancient Names, Capitano agreed to the Pyro Archon's plan and proposed joining forces to fight the Abyss. When the Abyss and its ultimate weapon, Gosoythoth, launched a full-scale invasion of Natlan, the Fatui fought alongside the warriors of Natlan. During the battle, the last heroine of Natlan was recognized by her Ancient Name, allowing the Pyro Archon to use the power granted by Ronova. According to the deal Xbalanque made with the Ruler of Death over a thousand years ago, the Pyro Archon could use Ronova's power, but the price for it was death. This power allowed Mavuika to banish Gosoythoth into the depths of the night realm and then descend there along with the Traveler, completely destroying the Abyss in Natlan.

When Mavuika went to meet with the Ruler of Death and the Lord of the Night to give up her life, she wanted to sacrifice her life force to the angel to prolong the life of the Ley Lines. When Ronova agreed to the terms of the deal, the Lord of the Night informed her that Capitano had approached her with the same proposal, and she confirmed the feasibility of his plan. The Harbinger wanted to change the rules of the Ley Lines, and the angel agreed, for many homeless souls were wandering Natlan. The Ley Lines could not accept these souls, but by becoming one with the Lord of the Night, Capitano could change the laws that governed them so that the souls could find peace. Although such changes were too risky and unacceptable in the eyes of the Heavenly Principles, the angels' primary mission was to serve humans. Despite her power, Mavuika could only ensure the existence of the Ley Lines for a few centuries, and then the next Pyro Archon would be forced to find a new way. Capitano, with the curse of immortality, wanted to merge with the Lord of the Night to allow her to live forever. The Harbinger wanted to take revenge and challenge the Ruler of Death. If he gave his life to the Lord of the Night, Ronova's will would be fulfilled, and she would get the death she desired. However, the curse of immortality would cancel this death. Left unresolved, such a contradiction would be able to shake the "reason" of this world, and not even the shade could bear the consequences of such an outcome. The Harbinger wanted to turn Ronova's curse into power to overthrow the oppression of the gods.

The Lord of the Night accepted Capitano's sacrifice, merging with him as one, and all the souls that had been stored in the Harbinger's heart for five hundred years were finally able to return to the Night Kingdom and find peace. Capitano himself, having "frozen" life and death, remained seated on the Throne of the Primal Fire, where Xbalanque had once made a deal with Ronova. For those cursed with immortality, the highest form of peace is liberation from the shackles of the world, and his path was finally over. The Ruler of Death could not lift the curse of immortality, so she had to refuse the price for using her power, allowing the Night Kingdom to exist forever and accept all souls.
<color=#ffffffd9>"A noble figure coats the sun with frost, and two eras grant salvation to Natlan not once, but twice."</color>
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Mavuika
customize.desc: The leader of Natlan who inherited the Ancient Name of "Kiongozi." She made a vow to illuminate the future of the nation of war with the Sacred Flame.

customize.text: Character Story

<color=#ffd780>Character Story 5</color>
Mavuika always imagined her plan to fight against the Abyss as a lengthy journey, and herself as an adventurer carrying a full pack and marching toward her predetermined goal. Memory and love were the supplies she brought, and they would help see her through confusion and solitude.
Within a world created through meditation, she would manifest this path. A high tower would appear in the distance, the Sacred Flame burning at its summit, lighting her way and showing her the path.
None knew how to get there, nor how far the journey would take her, but as her luggage grew ever lighter, the road stretched ever farther on with each step she took.
Farewell, Atea said to her, and Tenoch, and her mother and sister.
Farewell, Sundjatta told her, and Burkina and Wanjiru also.
The existence of the path to victory was not something to be taken for granted. Rather, it was forged by countless heroes, past and present. Rather than a "savior," then, Mavuika preferred to be known as an "agent."
But this alone was not enough. Her journey was no penance that required only willpower, but rather, decisiveness and wisdom also.
She could never have foreseen such marked variables as the Traveler or The Captain five hundred years prior, but upon learning of them, she only needed a moment's consideration before deciding to incorporate them into the plan.
In addition to any other considerations she might have had based on the realities of the situation, another factor played into her judgment — that both the Traveler and The Captain exhibited traits that mirrored her own.
Were it not for their respective positions, she would have liked nothing more than for the three of them to sit and speak of their travels over grilled meat and drinks. After all, those who travel along the same road, never having a fixed residence, can best resonate with and understand one another.
But she also had a deep understanding of the obstacles therein — having traveled so far, it was only natural to not wish to show the fatigue or weakness in one's heart, and even she was no exception.
She could easily tell stories about her comrades or family with a smile, but rarely could she speak of the sadness sown in the river of time by those happy moments, nor could she take out her long-emptied haversack, point at it, and speak of how it reflected the current state of her heart.
She could not, she would not, and she did not need to.
So, in the end, she kept a suitable distance, just as she always has. Everyone needed the ringing cheers and flowing wine of victory feasts, just as they needed the solitary quiet once the revelry faded.
In this era, perhaps only one person would ever inappropriately knock on her door in those peaceful moments, and that was Citlali.
Perhaps it was her fondness for drink? Or maybe they just made suitable drinking buddies.
Voice-Over

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
For him, I suspect the past five hundred years felt endless. When someone is deprived of death, life becomes a journey with no end, and the human spirit easily grows weary. And yet, he managed to seize the only chance of victory to arrive at the end he sought all along. I have great respect for warriors like him.
Dialogues

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
<color=#37ffff>Paimon</color> : Wait, if there are records of all this, that must mean The Captain was famous in Natlan!
<color=#37ffff>Mavuika</color> : Yes, but unless he brings up his past, few are likely to make the connection between a Fatui Harbinger and Thrain, one of Natlan's legendary heroes.

customize.name: Arlecchino
customize.desc: "The Knave," Fourth of the Fatui Harbingers. A poised, ruthless diplomat. To the children in the House of the Hearth, she is their feared yet dependable "Father."

customize.text: Voice-Over

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
He is very powerful, and that power comes with a high level of responsibility. However, I believe him to be someone worthy of respect independent of the power he holds.

customize.name: Wanderer
customize.desc: A wayfaring figure whose identity is a mystery. He dresses like a mountain ascetic, but he certainly does not act the part.

customize.text: Voice-Over

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
"The ever-righteous Captain," "the brave and fearless Captain," "the nigh-invincible Captain"... Even my mechanical ears demand maintenance after listening to so many compliments from the members of the Fatui. Don't you think that possessing absolute righteousness is actually a latent danger? And that's without taking his great personal strength into account.

customize.name: Tartaglia
customize.desc: No. 11 of The Harbingers, also known as "Childe." His name is highly feared on the battlefield.

customize.text: Voice-Over

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
I've seen him in battle before, and oh what a sight it was. Perhaps I'm ranked too low for him to notice me right now. Well, he may not recognize my strengths yet, but one day, I'll show him what I'm made of.

customize.name: Ororon
customize.desc: A young man from the Masters of the Night-Wind who instead lives in the wild alongside all manner of life.

customize.text: Character Story

<color=#ffd780>Character Story 5</color>
Late one night when the weather was mild, he sat by a campfire with the Fatui, quietly listening to what they had to say.
He was the only one who stayed quiet, aside from The Captain, who joined them later. The soldiers themselves did not hold back — it was clear they were already aware that he was working with their commander. The things they talked about were of no particular importance, yet they spoke and laughed freely, showing no restraint on account of his presence. After asking his age, one soldier even handed him a cup of a colorless drink they called "Fire-Water."
After a cautious sip, he proceeded to down it in one gulp, just as he had seen the soldiers do, receiving a loud cheer in response. For some reason, he felt a lot better after doing this.
The soldiers around him chatted about trivial matters, every now and then breaking into songs they all knew. Ororon did not have much to add, so he simply sat there, either watching the fire before them or the sky high above. It felt so far from the ground, the individual stars like tiny white kernels, together like mist. "Astral Mist," he suddenly thought to himself. Not a bad name...
Later, he would learn that not all Fatui soldiers were like this. The ones he met were elite soldiers led by the First Harbinger, older veterans with experience and firm moral standards. Beyond this company, however, there were many others who were younger than he was, others whose actions would leave his brows well and truly furrowed.
But on that windless night, with the stars so clearly visible in the sky, he had not yet been troubled by such knowledge. He simply let go of his worries, enjoying the friendly company and the cup of strange-tasting liquor he had been given.
There would never be another night like this. He sensed it then — just like how, when he considered accepting a second drink, he was firmly stopped by The Captain. Though he seemed completely normal after the first cup and potentially could really hold his liquor, yet all the same, some places are best not delved into too deeply.
But clearly, Ororon was not exactly the obedient type. Later, he discreetly tracked down the soldier who had handed him that drink and asked him how to brew Fire-Water himself. If he ever managed to make a batch clear enough to reflect the night sky, he'd name the first bottle "Astral Mist."
Voice-Over

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
Meeting The Captain was a strange and unexpected twist of fate for me.
My tribe is known for our - ability to predict the future, but I never expected things would turn out so complicated. Is helping someone really about trading favors until the score is even? If so, why do I still feel so indebted to him? So grateful for what he did for me?
Or... maybe I'm overthinking everything. No matter what happened in the past, he helped save Natlan's Ley Lines. He's a hero worthy of respect, and I'll always remember him.
<color=#ffd780>Least Favorite Food</color>
Military rations... especially compressed biscuits. They kinda remind me of The Captain's soul, actually... Good at the core, but a little tough.

customize.name: Mika
customize.desc: A young knight born to an ordinary family. He serves as a Front-Line Surveyor in his Company. He is a low-key and cautious character.

customize.text: Character Story

<color=#ffd780>Character Story 4</color>
As Mika continuously refined his skills in real-life combat, he became a core member of the Reconnaissance Company in less than two years, completing countless missions alongside his teammates.
The scheduled date drew near, and the expedition team was soon about to depart.
At the send-off party, Grand Master Varka was pleasantly surprised by the shiny new Vision on Mika's right wrist. But after personally inviting Mika to spar, he concluded that Mika's current abilities were "remarkable, but far from enough."
Mika didn't figure out what that meant until the expedition team entered a dangerous restricted area, where he finally saw with his own eyes the monsters Grand Master Varka had used as a reference when judging his powers.
Those unnamable, wandering creatures could become a nightmare for any knight unfortunate enough to stray away from the team.
The speed of their scouts in the vanguard determined how fast the whole expedition team proceeded, so during the days when the team was the busiest, Mika could only rest for half an hour a day.
It was Mika's first time working under such high pressure, and he did so with great difficulty. Not to mention that apart from dangers of the unknown, the expedition team was under the watchful gaze of another party...
One day, when Mika was getting ready to call it a night, he received a warning from another scout that the Knights had encountered enemies.
When Mika hurried on scene, Varka had already drawn up battle lines with his trusty subordinates.
In the depths of the pitch-dark night, Mika could vaguely make out a line of soldiers, silently standing there as if they were lifeless war machines.
And right in the middle of the enemy formation was a dark, distinct silhouette. Even though torches lit the area, Mika could see nothing but their eerily dark blue eyes that seemed to glow with an uncanny aura.
At his teammate's reminder, Mika learned of their identity — the Fatui Harbinger known as "The Captain" and his direct, elite subordinates.
As it turned out, their vanguard had bumped into Fatui scouts and an altercation had ensued, resulting in both sides getting jumpy and continuously requesting reinforcements, eventually alerting their respective commanders.
The scent of gunpowder was thick in the air, the sense of crisis turned Mika's limbs numb and cold.
He couldn't help visualizing the confrontation escalating into an armed conflict, and what he should do if such a thing were to happen...
The Harbinger, in particular — Mika knew that he would be utterly helpless to parry a single half-hearted swipe from this person.
His jumbled thoughts and exhaustion made it difficult to breathe or focus.
Varka, however, seemed completely unfazed. He greeted the Harbinger from afar and walked towards him with his weapon in hand. The Captain, too, signaled his men to stand by as he began slowly stepping forward.
As the tension between the two parties reached its peak, Varka and The Captain briefly conversed and seemed to reach an agreement.
The dark silhouette raised his arm, and the ghostly shadows of the Fatui soldiers silently turned and departed with him.
The Knights all heaved a sigh of relief, and some were even trembling with fear. But when Varka returned to the Knights' formation, he looked as relaxed as ever.
"Well, that was a surprise! If it weren't for our unique circumstances, I would've loved to invite him for a duel!"
"And it's not like he's a stubborn fellow. He's well aware that engaging in battle in a strange and foreign land would've been disadvantageous for both of us."
It was until then that Mika realized they had been on the precipice of war, and conflict had been avoided only because the Grand Master had been there to prevent it.
The Captain's overpowering presence and the calmness with which Grand Master Varka handled the crisis both left a profound impression in Mika's mind.
Mika reflected on this experience for a long time and concluded that although he had been improving in strength, he still had a long way to go when it came to dealing with situations like that.
There was more to be done than just doing his best to help the team. He had to work harder to become a reliable Knight who could handle all manner of incidents...
Voice-Over

<color=#ffd780>About Varka: The Captain</color>
The Grand Master said that I need to set higher goals for myself, and strive to achieve them. I've always had that kind of attitude, but it wasn't until I was on the expedition that I realized how serious things can become... One day, I met the Fatui Harbinger known as The Captain. I can't even begin to imagine how I can deal with an opponent like him. I just... Such powerful people are really on a level of their own, I'm not even remotely close...
Dialogues

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
<color=#37ffff>Mikhail</color> : Did you hear what happened with The Captain?
<color=#37ffff>Lyudmila</color> : Ah... I heard a few whispers. Apparently, the Tsaritsa has decided to keep his position as-is...
<color=#37ffff>Mikhail</color> : The Captain must have had his reasons for doing what he did, and the Abyss is not a foe to be taken lightly...
<color=#37ffff>Lyudmila</color> : What's this? A rare lapse in your bullish optimism?
<color=#37ffff>Mikhail</color> : ...Well, he did manage to earn everyone a valuable reprieve, including us, wouldn't you say?
<color=#37ffff>Mikhail</color> : And I've heard tell from our returning comrades that there's something wrong with the sky above Natlan.
<color=#37ffff>Lyudmila</color> : Ah! Has an even greater calamity befallen us?
<color=#37ffff>Mikhail</color> : Perhaps a calamity, or perhaps an opportunity... Why else would the powers that be suddenly dispatch more hands to a place like Nod-Krai?
<color=#ffffff>Natlanese</color>
Dialogues

<color=#ffd780>About The Captain</color>
When I was little, my father told me about Thrain, the "Sentinel Knight," an outlander who once fought alongside the warriors of Natlan.
He was brave, fearless, and deeply respected by his men. I always wished I could go back in time and see him in action...
I never thought that, in my lifetime, another outlander would fight to save this land, or that I would get the chance to fight by their side. I will treasure this honor for the rest of my life.
I knew about The Captain's immense strength, but I never expected him to have a such a strong sense of honor.
No matter how prejudiced I may have been in the past, he now has my utmost respect.

value.text:
The First of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers
Sentinel Knight
Thrain
